In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Certainly! In Julia, you can write a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(strip(col)) * '_' * replace(lowercase(strip(col)), '-' => '_')
end
```

This function takes an `AbstractString` (which is any string in Julia) as input and returns a cleaned version of the column name. It first strips leading and trailing whitespace with `strip`, then lowercases the entire string. After that, it replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores using `replace`.

Here's how you can use the function:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my column-2")
"my_column_2"
```

Please note that the `strip` function in Julia does not remove internal whitespace by default, which is why we need to call it twice (once for leading and once for trailing whitespace). If you want to remove all internal whitespace as well, you would use a regular expression like this:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(replace(strip(col), r"\s+" => "_")) * '_' * replace(lowercase(strip(col)), '-' => '_')
end
```

This will replace all sequences of one or more whitespace characters with an underscore within the string.
